Hamilton (cramp) |away reports = |venue = [[Adelaide Oval]] |crowd = 11,000 |report ={{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article90877282 |title=Football. |newspaper=[[South Australian Chronicle]] |location=Adelaide |date=12 October 1889 |accessdate=21 December 2014 |page=15 |via=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37175326 |title=FOOTBALL. |newspaper=[[The South Australian Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=21 June 1887 |accessdate=25 February 2015 |page=7 |via=National Library of Australia}} |umpires = [[John Trait]] |BOG award = |BOG winner = |broadcast = |anthem = |notes= }} ===1904 SAFA Challenge Final=== {| style="margin-right:4px; margin-top:8px; float:right; border:1px #000 solid; -moz-border-radius:8px; border-radius:8px; background:#fff; font-family:Verdana; font-size:8pt; text-align:center;" |- | width=200 | ''1904 SAFA Challenge Final'' || ''G'' || ''B'' || ''Total'' |- | style="text-align:left" | [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] || '''9''' || '''8''' || '''62''' |- | style="text-align:left" | [[Port Adelaide Football Club|Port Adelaide]] || 8 || 10 || 58 |- | Venue: [[Jubilee Oval (Adelaide)|Jubilee Oval]] | colspan=3 | Crowd: 11,000http://www.norwoodfc.com.au/site/DefaultSite/filesystem/documents/memorablematches/1904SAFAGrandFinal.pdf | colspan=3 | |} The 1904 Grand Final was a memorable one for Norwood who were down by 35 points at three-quarter time against traditional rival Port Adelaide. Norwood then produced an extraordinary burst of football with a goal by centre half-forward Dean Dawson followed by two goals each from full forward, [[William Miller (Australian footballer)|Bill Miller]] and half-forward flanker, Stan Robinson. Norwood was only two points down with a minute remaining. Tommy Gibbons held a mark on a seemingly impossible angle. His kick sailed through the goal posts to give Norwood a four-point victory, 9.8 to 8.10. === 1957 SANFL Grand Final === The 1957 SANFL Grand Final holds the record for the largest crowd of 58,924 between the two clubs. This remains the fourth largest crowd for a football match in South Australia. Norwood led the match for the majority of the day but Port Adelaide's five-goal-to-two final quarter allowed them to win by 11 points claiming their fourth premiership in a row. === 1960 SANFL Preliminary Final === {| style="margin-right:4px; margin-top:8px; float:right; border:1px #000 solid; -moz-border-radius:8px; border-radius:8px; background:#fff; font-family:Verdana; font-size:8pt; text-align:center;" |- | width=200 | ''1960 SANFL Preliminary Final'' || ''G'' || ''B'' || ''Total'' |- | style="text-align:left" | [[Port Adelaide Football Club|Port Adelaide]] || 3 || 14 || 32 |- | style="text-align:left" | [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] || '''8''' || '''9''' || '''59''' |- | Venue: [[Adelaide Oval]] | colspan=3 | | colspan=3 | |} Port Adelaide had finished the home and away season as minor premier and looked on track to make rebound from the previous week's loss against North Adelaide to attempt to win its seventh consecutive premiership. Norwood, who had finished the home and away season in third place was desperate to beat Port Adelaide in the preliminary final in order to prevent the Magpies from bettering its run of six consecutive premierships set from 1878 to 1883. The weather was unfavourable, with a large amount of rain causing the ground to become slush. Commentators considered it one of the most brutal finals played in memory.{{Cite book|title = Bound for Glory|last = Wood|first = John|publisher = Largs Bay Printers|year = 1991|isbn = |location = Port Adelaide|pages = 87}} The game was in the balance heading into the final quarter with the scoreboard reflecting the scrappy nature of the game; Norwood 3.14 (32) lead Port Adelaide 3.10 (28). Norwood managed to adapt to the conditions in the final quarter kicking 5.1, whereas Port Adelaide could only muster 1.2. The final scores were in favour of Norwood 8.11 (59) to Port Adelaide 3.14 (32). It is a coincidence that Norwood brought an end to Port Adelaide's run of six premierships from 1954–1959 as Port Adelaide did the same to Norwood's run of six between 1878–1883. After the match during the dark of night [[Haydn Bunton Jr.|Haydn Bunton Jr]] and John Vickers went to Black Diamond Corner in Port Adelaide and painted it red and blue.{{Cite book|title = Red and blue blooded|last = Coward|first = Mike|publisher = Avant Garde Photocomposition|year = 1977|isbn = |location = |pages = 171}} === 1996 SANFL Preliminary Final === {| style="margin-right:4px; margin-top:8px; float:right; border:1px #000 solid; -moz-border-radius:8px; border-radius:8px; background:#fff; font-family:Verdana; font-size:8pt; text-align:center;" |- | width=200 | ''1996 SANFL Preliminary Final'' || ''G'' || ''B'' || ''Total'' |- | style="text-align:left" | [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] || 9 || 8 || 62 |- | style="text-align:left" | [[Port Adelaide Football Club|Port Adelaide]] || '''9''' || '''12''' ||''' 66''' |- | Venue: [[Football Park]] | colspan=3 | Crowd: 18,338 | colspan=3 | |} The game was close all the way through and Norwood was leading by two points deep into time on when Trevor Growden gave Scott Hodges a free kick in the north-west pocket of Football Park. Scott Hodges from 45m out on an angle of 45 degrees kicked the goal after missing easier shots throughout the match. This would be the two clubs final encounter before Port Adelaide entered the Australian Football League. ==Venues== The vast majority of the games played between Port Adelaide and Norwood have been at [[Alberton Oval]], [[Norwood Oval]], [[Football Park]], and [[Adelaide Oval]]. [[File:Plogging with Coastal Striders - FUNK9730 (42405061590).jpg|thumb|A woman bending to pick up litter while a man jogs alongside with a garbage bag at a plogging event in [[Kent]], England]]
'''Plogging''' is a combination of [[jogging]] with picking up [[litter]] (Swedish: ''plocka upp''). It started as an organised activity in [[Sweden]] around 2016 and spread to other countries in 2018, following increased concern about [[plastic pollution]]. As a workout, it provides variation in body movements by adding bending, squatting and stretching to the main action of running.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcthree/article/237c63d4-0a54-406a-ae51-ad677a872456|title=Plogging is the latest Scandinavian lifestyle trend to rock your world|last=Frymorgen|first=Tomasz|date=January 30, 2018|work=BBC|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/shortcuts/2018/feb/19/a-rubbish-way-to-get-fit-why-i-loved-going-plogging|title=A rubbish way to get fit – why I loved going ‘plogging’|last=Ross|first=Peter|date=February 19, 2018|work=The Guardian|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health-fitness/body/plogging-2018-fitness-trend-yet/|title=Is 'plogging' the most 2018 fitness trend yet?|last=Morrissy-Swan|first=Tomé|date=February 1, 2018|work=The Telegraph|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref>
Author [[David Sedaris]] combines litter picking with exercise in the [[Parham, West Sussex|Parham]], [[Coldwaltham]] and [[Storrington]] districts of [[West Sussex]], taking up to 60,000 steps a day in pursuit of local rubbish.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theage.com.au/lifestyle/health-and-wellness/plogging-the-fitness-trend-with-a-social-conscience-20180205-h0tx6r.html|title=Plogging: the fitness trend with a social conscience|last=Lytton|first=Charlotte|date=February 6, 2018|work=The Age|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref> He was so effective in keeping his neighbourhood clean that the local authority named a waste vehicle in his honour.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/shortcuts/2014/jul/31/david-sedaris-litter-picker-rubbish-waste-vehicle-pig-pen-west-sussex|title=David Sedaris? Who? Oh, you mean the local litter-picker|last=Dowling|first=Tim|date=July 31, 2014|work=The Guardian|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref> The [[Lord Lieutenant of West Sussex]], Susan Pyper, said "The sign on this truck is a very fitting way to say a huge ‘thank you’ to David for his tireless efforts ... he is a real local hero."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.westsussextoday.co.uk/news/south-downs-litter-picker-has-truck-named-after-him-1-6204429|title=South Downs litter picker has truck named after him|last=|first=|date=July 28, 2014|work=West Sussex Gazette|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref>
Erik Ahlström started plogging in the Swedish capital city, [[Stockholm]], when he moved there from the [[Åre ski resort]]. He created the website Plogga to organise the activity and encourage volunteers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.core77.com/posts/72971/New-Swedish-Fitness-Trend-Plogging-Combines-Jogging-with-Picking-Up-Litter|title=New Swedish Fitness Trend, "Plogging," Combines Jogging with Picking Up Litter|last=Noe|first=Rain|date=February 2, 2018|work=Core77|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref>
The [[Keep America Beautiful]] organisation is now promoting plogging to its affiliates and has found that some already combined exercise with clean up, such as the ''Trashercize'' program in Tennessee.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/inspired-life/wp/2018/02/23/plogging-is-the-swedish-fitness-craze-for-people-who-want-to-save-the-planet-its-making-its-way-to-the-u-s/|title=‘Plogging’ is the Swedish fitness craze for people who want to save the planet. It’s making its way to the U.S.|last=Klein|first=Allison|date=February 23, 2018|work=The Washington Post|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref> In New York, a [[Meetup (website)|Meetup]] group, ''Plogging NYC'', had about 100 members in 2018, with events [[Boroughs of New York City|in four boroughs]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/08/20/saving-the-planet-and-your-glutes|title=Saving the Planet and Your Glutes|last=Marx|first=Patricia|date=August 20, 2018|work=The New Yorker|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref> In Indianapolis in 2018, a Summer of Plogging was organised by the [[November Project]] and the local affiliate of [[Keep America Beautiful]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/news/2018/07/15/plogging-jogging-environmental-twist-picking-up-litter/760391002/|title=Plogging? You know, when you jog and pick up litter at the same time|last=Smith|first=Rachel|date=July 15, 2018|work=IndyStar|access-date=November 11, 2018}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://spark.adobe.com/page/JjtHQYm7ijmVg/ Plogga] – a Swedish plogging website * [https://m.facebook.com/plogit.org/ Plog It] – a networking & meet-up platform for Plogging and Photo-Blogging the impact created *[https://www.goplogging.org/ Go Plogging] – organises plogging meet ups in London, Paris and Miami
[[Category:Litter]] [[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:Plastics and the environment]] [[Category:Waste collection]]

Baton Rouge River Center Arena {{small|(2004-16)}} | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Baton Rouge River Center Arena.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_alt = | address = 275 River Rd S
[[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge, LA]] 70802-5809 | location = [[Baton Rouge River Center|Raising Cane's River Center]] | coordinates = | type = | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1977|01|14}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Baton Rouge Area Convention & Visitors Bureau | operator = [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] | surface = | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 8,900 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Baton Rouge Kingfish]] ([[ECHL]]) (1996–2003)
[[Baton Rouge Bombers]] ([[EISL]]) (1997–98)
[[Louisiana Bayou Beast]] ([[IPFL]]) (1999)
[[Baton Rouge Blaze]] ([[af2]]) (2001) | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} The '''Raising Cane's River Center Arena''' (originally the '''Riverside Centroplex Arena''' and commonly known as the '''River Center Arena''') is a multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]], in the [[United States]]. The arena can be combined with the exhibition hall to create more than 100,000 square feet (10,000 m²) of contiguous convention or exhibit space.http://www.brrivercenter.com/arena.cfm?s=1002118 The arena which opened in 1977 presents concerts, sporting events, theater events, trade shows, and family shows, with seating for up to 10,400 for concerts (permanent and floor seats), 8,900 for sporting events (permanent seats) and 4,500 for theatre events. In 2016, [[Raising Cane's Chicken Fingers]] signed a 10-year naming rights agreement for the arena.{{cite web |url=http://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/news/article_0b8ae22a-9bc5-11e6-9e10-5b639842b8d7.html |title=It's official: Baton Rouge River Center to become Raising Cane's River Center |last1=Gallo |first1=Andrea |last2= |first2= |date=October 26, 2016 |website=theadvocate.com |publisher=Georges Media |accessdate=April 12, 2017}} ==Teams== The arena has been home to multiple sports teams based in Baton Rouge. From 1996-2003, it was home to the [[Baton Rouge Kingfish]] hockey team of the ([[ECHL]]). Also during that time, the arena was home to the [[Baton Rouge Bombers]] indoor soccer team of the ([[EISL]]) from (1997-1998). The venue was home to two professional arena football teams, the [[Louisiana Bayou Beast]] of the ([[IPFL]]) in (1999) and the [[Baton Rouge Blaze]] of the ([[af2]]) in (2001).http://www.batonrougerivercenter.net/ ==See also== *[[Raising Cane's River Center]] *[[List of music venues]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://raisingcanesrivercenter.com/venues-services/ Venue website] {{Coord|30.4448|-91.1894|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Baton Rouge, Louisiana}} {{Music venues of Louisiana}} [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:Baton Rouge Bombers]] [[Category:Baton Rouge Kingfish arenas]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:Convention centers in Louisiana]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Professional wrestling venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues in Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Wrestling venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1977]] [[Category:Music venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:1977 establishments in Louisiana]] {{BatonRougeLA-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Sport overview | country = Bermuda | sport = rugby union | image = Bermudarugby.png | caption = Union logo | union = [[Bermuda Rugby Football Union]] | nickname = | first = Late 19th century | registered = 707 {{cite web |url=http://www.irb.com/unions/union=11000040/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110915192248/http://www.irb.com/unions/union=11000040/index.html |archivedate=2011-09-15 |df= }} | clubs = 4 | match = | national_list = [[Rugby World Cup]]
[[Rugby World Cup Sevens]]
[[IRB Sevens World Series]] | club_list = | countryflag = Bermuda }} '''Rugby union in Bermuda''' is a popular sport. Because of [[Bermuda]]'s small population, less than 70,000, it has not produced a world class [[rugby union]] team, but nonetheless is a dominant force within Caribbean rugby.Bath p63 The [[Bermuda Rugby Football Union]] was founded in 1964, and joined the IRB in 1992. ==History== As with many British colonies, rugby union was an early arrival in the island, being played since the 19th century. Rugby in the island has tended to be played by the white population, as well as some immigrants, such as former Bristol winger Barry Whitehead. Bermudian rugby suffered a major setback in 1958, when a regular Bermuda Rugby Week competition popular with U.S. teams was dropped by the sponsoring [[Bermuda Trade Development Board]] because of complaints about off-pitch behaviour.Richards, Chapter 10 ''Not-So Swinging '60s'', p184 Bermuda competes in the [[Caribbean Championship]], a tournament which includes [[Trinidad and Tobago national rugby union team|Trinidad and Tobago]], [[Martinique national rugby union team|Martinique]], the [[Cayman Islands national rugby union team|Cayman Islands]], [[Jamaica national rugby union team|Jamaica]], the [[Bahamas national rugby union team|Bahamas]], [[British Virgin Islands national rugby union team|British Virgin Islands]], [[Antigua and Barbuda national rugby union team|Antigua]] and [[Guyana national rugby union team|Guyana]].Bath p78 The highlight of the rugby year in Bermuda is the [[Bermuda Classic Tournament]]. This is a kind of Rugby World Cup for the over-35s. The island is also quite small measuring no more than twenty-one square miles. This coupled with its small population make it hard for a major rugby culture to emerge. ==See also== * [[Bermuda national rugby union team]] * [[Bermuda Rugby Football Union]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Bath, Richard (ed.) ''The Complete Book of Rugby'' (Seven Oaks Ltd, 1997 {{ISBN|1-86200-013-1}}) * Richards, Huw ''A Game for Hooligans: The History of Rugby Union'' ([[Mainstream Publishing]], [[Edinburgh]], 2007, {{ISBN|978-1-84596-255-5}}) ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110915192248/http://www.irb.com/unions/union=11000040/index.html IRB Bermuda page] * [http://bermudarfu.com/default.aspx Official union page] * [http://www.nawira.com/members/bermuda/ NAWIRA Bermuda Page] *{{fr}} [http://www.lestimbresdurugby.com/Archivesdurugby/Pays/Bermudes.htm Archives du Rugby: Bermudes] {{Rugby union outside WC}} {{North America in topic|Rugby union in}} {{Rugby union in British dependencies}} [[Category:Rugby union in Bermuda| ]] {{Bermuda-sport-stub}}

29200 [[Brest, France|Brest]] |tenants= [[Stade Brestois 29]] }} '''Stade Francis-Le Blé''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Brest, France|Brest]], [[France]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Stade Brestois 29]]. The stadium is able to hold 15,097 spectators. The stadium is named for [[Francis Le Blé]], former mayor of Brest who died in 1982.(27 April 2010). [http://www.brest.maville.com/actu/actudet_-D-Alex-a-Zorro-tout-sur-le-Stade-brestois-2009-2010-_loc-1346053_actu.Htm?xtor=RSS-4 D'Alex à Zorro, tout sur le Stade brestois 2009-2010], ''maville.com'' (noting that Le Blé died in 1982) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.sb29.com/stade-francis-le-ble.php Stade Brestois 29 Club Website] {{Ligue 2 venues}} {{Coord|48.402932|-4.461694|display=title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stade Francis-Le Ble}} [[Category:Stade Brestois 29|Francis le Ble]] [[Category:Football venues in France|Francis-Le Ble]] [[Category:Sports venues in Finistère]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Brest, France]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1922]] {{France-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = New George V Stadium | image = | location = Barry Road
[[Curepipe]]
[[Mauritius]] | coordinates = {{coord|20|19|16.56|S|57|31|46.74|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1954 | opened = 1955 | renovated = 9th August 2003 | construction_cost = Rs 135 million | surface = Grass | former_names = George V Stadium | tenants = [[Mauritius national football team]], [[Curepipe Starlight SC]], [[AS de Vacoas-Phoenix]] | capacity = 6500 | scoreboard = }} '''New George V Stadium''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Curepipe]], [[Mauritius]]. The stadium holds 6,500 people.http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/mauritius.shtml == History == The construction of the George V Stadium started in 1954 and the stadium was ready in 1955.http://www.mauritiusfootball.com/mf-history.php In November 2002, the old stadium was demolished and the new stadium was reopened in August 2003. It was used in the [[Indian Ocean Island Games]] in [[2003 Indian Ocean Games|2003]] and has been the [[Mauritius national football team|national team]] home ground ever since. However, some matches are also played at the [[Stade Anjalay|Anjalay Stadium]]. ==External links== *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/africa/mauritius/curepipe_george.shtml Photo] at [http://www.worldstadiums.com/ worldstadiums.com] *[http://www.fussballtempel.net/caf/MRI/George_V.html Photo] at [http://www.fussballtempel.net/ fussballtempel.net] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Curepipe]] [[Category:Football venues in Mauritius]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Mauritius]] {{Mauritius-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{About|the sports phrase|the foodstuff|Canned tomatoes}}
In [[boxing]], [[kickboxing]] or [[mixed martial arts]], "'''tomato can'''" or simply "'''tomato'''" or "'''can'''" is an [[idiom]] for a fighter with poor or diminished skills (at least when compared with the opponent they are placed against) who may be considered an easy opponent to defeat, or a "guaranteed win." Fights with "tomato cans" can be arranged to inflate the win total of a professional fighter. Similarly, a fighter whose record consists of wins over easy opponents is referred to as a "can crusher".<ref>http://www.cagepotato.com/8-greatest-can-crushers-mma/</ref> The phrase originates in the childhood pastime of kicking a can down the street—a boxer is advancing his career with minimal effort by defeating a "tomato can" and notching a win. "Tomato" refers to blood: "knock a tomato can over, and red stuff spills out."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/projects/2013/tomato-can-blues/ |author=Mary PIlon |title=Tomato Can Blues |work=New York Times |date= |accessdate=2015-10-29}}</ref>
==Characteristics== A "tomato can" is usually a fighter with a poor record, whose skills are substandard or who lacks toughness or has a "[[Chin (boxing)|glass chin]]." Sometimes a formerly successful boxer who is past his prime and who has seen his skills diminish is considered a "tomato can" if he can no longer compete at a high level. Such an individual is an attractive opponent if his name still carries prestige but his diminished skills make him an easy conquest. When referring to a distinguished fighter, opponents with passable careers who simply aren't at the same level can also be considered "tomato cans". Most fighters who are considered "tomato cans" are [[heavyweight]]s, because at lower weight classes one must maintain a certain level of fitness in order to make weight, whereas a heavyweight who once fought at a trim 205 pounds could conceivably gain 150 pounds and still fight in the same division.
One characteristic which may account for the use of the "tomato can" metaphor for a bad boxer is the tendency to leak "tomato juice" (i.e., blood) when battered.
"Tomato cans" are similar to [[Job (professional wrestling)|jobbers]] in [[professional wrestling]] in that they serve to enhance the stature of someone the promotion uses to draw a crowd.
==Surprises and upsets== Victory over a "tomato can" is not a certainty. [[Journeyman (sports)|Journeyman]] boxers generally regarded as "tomato cans" have been known to provide surprising challenges to champions and in several instances, cause shocking [[Upset (competition)|upset]]s against supposedly superior opponents.
On March 24, 1975, [[Muhammad Ali]] faced [[Chuck Wepner]], a lightly regarded but popular boxer from [[New Jersey]]. A former nightclub bouncer, Wepner was nicknamed "The Bayonne Bleeder" and was considered a washed-up contender with a mediocre record. [[Don King (boxing promoter)|Don King]] selected Wepner as a "tomato can" to provide an easy victory for Ali after his famous win over [[George Foreman]].<ref>[http://www.njboxinghof.org/cgi-bin/henryseehof.pl?191 CHUCK WEPNER], New Jersey Boxing Hall of Fame, 1982-10-29, Retrieved on 2007-03-31.</ref> In a surprising turn of events, Wepner scored a disputed knockdown in the ninth round, and survived 19 seconds short of the distance, before losing by [[Technical Knockout|TKO]] in the 15th round.<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/features/1998/holyfield/tomatocans/3.html Tomato Cans: MUHAMMAD ALI vs. CHUCK WEPNER], [[CNN]] / [[Sports Illustrated|SI]]'', Retrieved on 2007-03-31.</ref> Wepner's bout with Ali provided the inspiration for [[Sylvester Stallone]]'s movie ''[[Rocky]]''.<ref>[http://www.planetrapture.com/wepner.htm CHUCK WEPNER, THE REAL ROCKY], Planetrapture.com, Retrieved on 2007-03-31.</ref>
In a fight on February 11, 1990, [[Mike Tyson]] lost his championship to [[Buster Douglas|James "Buster" Douglas]] in Tokyo.<ref name="buster">Kincade, Kevin., [http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=4063&more=1 "The Moments": Mike Tyson vs Buster Douglas] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130145640/http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=4063&more=1 |date=November 30, 2010 }}, Eastsideboxing.com, 2005-07-12, Retrieved on 2007-03-26.</ref> The victory over Tyson, the previously undefeated "baddest man on the planet" and the most feared boxer in professional boxing at that time, at the hands of the 42–1 [[betting odds]] [[Underdog (competition)|underdog]] Douglas, has been described as one of the most shocking [[Upset (competition)|upset]]s in modern sports history.<ref>Staff, [http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/010523upset.html Page 2's List for top upset in sports history], [[ESPN]].com, 2001-05-23, Retrieved on 2007-03-26.</ref> Douglas was widely regarded as a "tomato can", lined up to provide an easy victory for Tyson at that time. Later, Douglas lost his first title defense against [[Evander Holyfield]] and was never able to successfully compete at such a high level again.<ref>Kanew, Evan., [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/features/1998/holyfield/tomatocans/9.html Tomato Cans:JAMES (BUSTER) DOUGLAS vs. MIKE TYSON], ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', Retrieved on 2008-01-15.</ref>
The biggest upset in mixed martial arts is considered by many, including UFC president [[Dana White]] and [[ESPN]], to be [[Matt Serra]]'s TKO victory over UFC Welterweight Champion [[Georges St. Pierre]] at [[UFC 69]] on April 7, 2007, as an 11–1 underdog.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/extra/mma/photos/gallery/_/id/8323302/image/6/matt-serra-georges-st-pierre-ufc-69-five-biggest-upsets|title=No. 1: Matt Serra-Georges St. Pierre (UFC 69) - Five Biggest Upsets |publisher=ESPN.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/ufc/story/dana-white-tate-beating-rousey-would-be-ufc-s-second-biggest-upset-ever-122613|title=Dana White: Tate beating Rousey would be UFC's second biggest upset ever |author=Damon Martin |date=December 7, 2013|publisher=FOX Sports}}</ref>

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Yaoundé Multipurpose Sports Complex | former_names = | image = Yaoundé Sports Palace 2014 (05).JPG | location = [[Yaoundé]], [[Cameroon]] | opened = June 19, 2009 | renovated = | owner = | tenants = | architect = | seating_capacity = 5,263 }} The '''Yaoundé Multipurpose Sports Complex''' (French: ''Palais polyvalent des sports de Yaoundé'') is an [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] located in [[Yaoundé]], [[Cameroun]]. The capacity of the arena is 5,263 people. It is used to host indoor sports such as [[basketball]].
It was built by the [[People's Republic of China]] and was inaugurated on June 19, 2009.
==Photos== <gallery> Yaoundé Sports Palace 2014 (02).JPG|Side view Yaoundé Sports Palace 2014 (12).JPG|Inside view Yaoundé Sports Palace 2014 (09).JPG|A plaque commemorating the inauguration Yaoundé Sports Palace 2014 (07).JPG|Cameroonian and Chinese flags flying in front of the Sports Palace </gallery>
